product Feedback
• It's hard to remember to give out tokens every day. I'm tempted to build a script to do it for me.
    ◦ This is fair, but you don't have to give rewards everyday. We have automated Slack notifications that remind you to give rewards if you go several days without giving a reward. Giving rewards everyday only benefits you by increasing your user point score (top right of screen), which currently are not actionable or spendable.
• Can tokens accumulate until I give them out?
    ◦ The ONLY team that has a fixed number of rewards to give is the Nerd United team. All other teams, including your chain team, are slice-of-pie instead of allotment projects, which means you can give as many rewards as you want at any time. For the Nerd United team, rewards-to-give do not accumulate.
• Sometimes it's hard to think of what to say in the rewards, and I wish there was a way to make that easier. It's not for lack of reasons to give--but from not wanting to give introverted, one-word awards.
    ◦ This is great feedback, and we're looking for ways to either connect rewards to events (valuable slack messages, jira tickets, etc), or AI-assisted reward message creation.
• Is the goal to _only_ give them out to exceptional people, even if you only give out one reward a day, or is the goal to find *three people every day* who deserve them the most?
    ◦ The goal is to give them to whomever you feel deserves a reward. As I said above, you can give as many rewards as you want in any project other than the Nerd United project. Therefore, it doesn't matter if you give 1 reward or 50 rewards a day as long as you feel you have something meaningful to say.
• It takes _so_ long to save up 50 points, can we make 30 the threshold?
    ◦ I agree with you, I only just got to 50 points in the Nerd United project. This is definitely something we'll consider.
• Sometimes I’m more interested in giving tokens to whichever top-ten person I want to stay on the leaderboard, or whoever is closest to earning the 50 points needed to cash out, since anything else feels like throwing pennies in a well.
    ◦ This is tied to the issue of what is the inherent value behind rewards, and we just hired a gamification specialist to solve this problem!
• I liked the addition of the “top awards” because it encouraged me to be more creative with my compliments to people
    ◦ Love this, I hope we can find more ways to incentivize this kind of behavior
• The battle for the top spot on the leaderboard is hard to topple if it doesn’t reset every so often. If the leaderboard doesn't reset, then I just end up throwing tokens at whoever piques my interest on the leaderboard, instead of who actually deserved it that day.
    ◦ We are building out leaderboard with growth metrics that show who is growing the most instead of total points/rewards, but that's definitely a good idea to build reward functionality to topple leaderboard toppers
• In the slice-of-pie projects, there is no way for me to see my giving progress for a given month. If this is a determining factor in peoples bonus, I don't feel equipped. What if I only give out one reward a week and end up forgetting all the other awesome things other people did? How do I keep track of my giving so I can make sure it's balanced?
    ◦ The idea is that if something is valuable enough, product users will take the minute it takes to give a reward to that person. However, if the platform doesn't make that transaction valuable or easy enough, that's definitely something we need to solve.
These are my responses to this person, in case this answers some of your questions as well.

I'm a little confused by the prime survey questions, but here is some feedback I've been chewing on~~

product Feedback
• It's hard to remember to give out tokens every day. I'm tempted to build a script to do it for me.
• Can tokens accumulate until I give them out?
• Sometimes it's hard to think of what to say in the rewards, and I wish there was a way to make that easier. It's not for lack of reasons to give--but from not wanting to give introverted, one-word awards.
• Is the goal to _only_ give them out to exceptional people, even if you only give out one reward a day, or is the goal to find *three people every day* who deserve them the most?
• It takes _so_ long to save up 50 points, can we make 30 the threshold?
• Sometimes I’m more interested in giving tokens to whichever top-ten person I want to stay on the leaderboard, or whoever is closest to earning the 50 points needed to cash out, since anything else feels like throwing pennies in a well.
• I liked the addition of the “top awards” because it encouraged me to be more creative with my compliments to people
• The battle for the top spot on the leaderboard is hard to topple if it doesn’t reset every so often. If the leaderboard doesn't reset, then I just end up throwing tokens at whoever piques my interest on the leaderboard, instead of who actually deserved it that day.
• In the slice-of-pie projects, there is no way for me to see my giving progress for a given month. If this is a determining factor in peoples bonus, I don't feel equipped. What if I only give out one reward a week and end up forgetting all the other awesome things other people did? How do I keep track of my giving so I can make sure it's balanced?

This is feedback I got from someone who has given a lot of feedback in the past, I think it highlights several issues I've noticed about prime and touches on some stuff I think that can be solved through proper implementation of gamification techniques

It might be a good idea for you to do two different displays for response rate on sentiment analysis. One that shows total number of questions answered divided by total number of questions available (like number of team members X number of questions), and one that shows total number of people that have completed all the questions.
Good question, I'm not entirely sure, let me check
Thanks man!
The average of all scores for a given category, or for all categories when calculating total team score

nps stands for net promoter score. We calculate it by taking all of the responses of that category (responses being a number from 1-7) and dividing it by the total quantity of responses for that category.
Does this make sense to you? It tells what each of the buckets are

case when nps < 0 then ‘needs attention’
     when nps < 40 then ‘poor’
     when nps < 70 then ‘average’
     when nps < 101 then ‘good’ end as nps_cat,
